Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Statistical Inference for Functional and High Dimensional Data with New Dependence Metrics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to the rapid development of information technologies and their applications in many scientific fields such as climate science, medical imaging, and finance, statistical analysis of high-dimensional data and infinite-dimensional functional data has become increasingly important. A key challenge associated with the analysis of such big data is how to measure and infer complex dependence structure, which is a fundamental step in statistics and becomes more difficult owing to the data's high dimensionality and huge size. The main goal of this research project is to develop new dependence measures for quantifying dependence of large scale data sets such as temporally dependent functional data and high dimensional data, and utilize these new measures to develop novel statistical tools for conducting sparse principal component analysis, dimensional reduction, and simultaneous hypothesis testing. Building on the new dependence metrics that can capture nonlinear and non-monotonic dependence, the methodologies under development are expected to lead to more accurate prediction and inference, as well as more effective dimension reduction in the analysis of functional and high dimensional data.

The research consists of three projects addressing different challenges in the analysis of functional and high dimensional data. In Project 1, the investigators introduce a new operator-valued quantity to characterize the conditional mean (in)dependence of one function-valued random element given another, and apply the newly developed dependent metrics to do dimension reduction for functional time series under a new framework of finite dimensional functional data. In Project 2, the investigators explore a new dimension reduction framework for regression models with high dimensional response, which requires less stringent linear model assumptions and is more flexible in terms of capturing possible nonlinear dependence between the response and the covariates. In Project 3, the investigators develop new tests for the mutual independence of high dimensional data via distance covariance and rank distance covariance using both sum of squares and maximum type test statistics. Overall, the three lines of research are all related to big data, and they touch upon various aspects of modern statistics; the project aims to push the current frontiers in areas including sparse principal component analysis, inference for dependent functional data, and high dimensional multivariate analysis to another level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this proposal, our goal is to develop new dependence metrics building on distance covariance and
distance correlation as well as their variants and advance them into important inference problems associated with temporally dependent functional data and high-dimensional data. When dealing with functional data or high-dimensional data with multivariate
response, dimension reduction becomes a necessary step. Most existing tools, such as classical principal
component analysis and canonical correlation analysis, are based on linear dependence measures, and are
not tailored to handle data that exhibit nonlinearity and are thus suboptimal. The new dimension reduction
and inference tools we want to develop are built on the nonlinear dependence metrics which can capture
both linear and nonlinear dependence and have shown great promise in dealing with high-dimensional data and
 temporally dependent functional data. Additionally some novel testing procedures will be developed to assess the
mutual dependence in high-dimensional data.



During the funding period, the PI has successfully developed several new nonlinear dependence metrics such as martingale difference divergence and its matrix-valued variant, to measure the mean dependence of a random vector (or function) given another one. These new metrics are then used to test for mean dependence with high-dimensional covariates, reduce the dimension in the modeling of multivariate stationary time series for both conditional mean and conditional volatility, and test for the dependence in the context of functional data.  On the scientific front, the resulting statistical significance tests can be widely used to test for potential dependence in both high-dimensional and functional data, and the dimension reduction methods can be used to build a more accurate forecasting model.  On the theory front, the PI has developed rigorous asymptotic theory to accompany all novel methodology and
extended the theory for classical U-statistics to the high-dimensional setting. On the educational front, the PI has supervised several Ph.D. students in the area of high-dimensional data analysis, functional data analysis and time series analysis.   The PI has disseminated research results by publishing them at top statistics and econometrics journals, and presenting different parts of the research at a number of conferences and department seminars. An R package "EDmeasure" has been developed with collaborators and students to allow interested users to have access to the codes.
